diagnosis.score_summary: eos demonstrates near-perfect discipline across channels, maintaining a cohesive 'Hyper-Elevated Cozy' identity. The deviations found are not contradictions, but highly specific platform optimizations that prove the brand understands the difference between 'Showcasing' (WWW) and 'Selling' (PDP).

truth_1.headline: Editors vs. The Mob
truth_1.gap_description: WWW validates quality via Authority (Allure Award). PDP validates quality via Volume (54k Reviews). One signals 'Expert Approved,' the other signals 'Crowd Favorite.'
truth_1.evidence: WWW: 'Awarded Allure Beauty Expert Seal' (Validator: 3/5) vs. PDP: '54,062 global ratings' (Validator: 5/5)
truth_1.why_matters: The brand creates a subtle hierarchy conflict. Is this a curated product for the 'Vanilla Girl' elite, or a mass-market commodity that 'everyone' buys? The prestige of the seal fights the ubiquity of the review count.
truth_1.the_hard_choice: You are currently balancing on the razor's edge between Boutique and Commodity. The data demands a choice in validation strategy: either elevate the Amazon listing by prioritizing the 'Allure' badge to maintain the premium illusion (Option A), or flood the website with the '54k Reviews' graphic to surrender to the power of the mob (Option B). An award implies taste; a review count implies safety.

truth_2.headline: The Cheeky vs. The Clean
truth_2.gap_description: WWW leans into 'The Jester' (Secondary Archetype), using cheeky viral language. PDP swaps the secondary archetype for 'The Innocent,' emphasizing purity and safety.
truth_2.evidence: WWW: '#vanillagirl era' (Jester) vs. PDP: 'Soothe and protect' / 'Hypoallergenic' (Innocent)
truth_2.why_matters: On the site, you are a 'Cool Friend.' On Amazon, you are a 'Safe Product.' This personality split dilutes the 'Cool' factor for the Amazon shopper who encounters a more sanitized version of the brand.
truth_2.the_hard_choice: You are code-switching between a party girl and a nurse. To build a singular icon, you must choose: either sanitize the website to match the safe, 'Innocent' promise of the Amazon listing (Option A), or infect the Amazon PDP with the 'Jester' energy of the website to prove you are actually cool (Option B). Safety prevents returns, but personality builds cults.

truth_3.headline: Too Cool vs. Trying Hard
truth_3.gap_description: WWW uses high Formality (Slang) to appear effortlessly cool. PDP uses high Enthusiasm (Hype) to shout features. The website whispers 'if you know, you know,' while Amazon screams 'Pro Tip!'
truth_3.evidence: WWW: 'Step into your #vanillagirl era' (Cool) vs. PDP: 'We'll do the rest!' (Hype)
truth_3.why_matters: Enthusiasm is the opposite of Cool. By shouting on Amazon, you break the 'Insider' frame established on the website. You risk looking desperate to the marketplace shopper.
truth_3.the_hard_choice: The tone gap reveals a tension between status and salesmanship. You must decide: either lower the energy on Amazon to maintain the 'Cool Girl' detachment of the website (Option A), or ramp up the enthusiasm on the website to match the high-conversion energy of the marketplace (Option B). You cannot be both an aloof icon and a cheerleading salesperson.

truth_4.headline: The Trend Trap
truth_4.gap_description: Both channels score 100% on 'The Trend-Setter' marker, heavily relying on the '#vanillagirl' viral moment. This is consistent, but dangerous.
truth_4.why_matters: Trends rot faster than fruit. By anchoring your identity so firmly to a specific TikTok aesthetic (#vanillagirl), you risk immediate obsolescence when the internet moves to the next 'Era.'
truth_4.the_hard_choice: You have mortgaged your brand identity to a hashtag. This drives short-term volume but guarantees long-term expiry. You face a strategic ultimatum: either diversify the aesthetic now to survive the inevitable death of the 'Vanilla Girl' trend (Option A), or ride this rocket into the ground and accept that you will have to rebrand from scratch in 12 months (Option B). Relevance is a drug, and withdrawal is painful.

truth_5.headline: The Price is the Power
truth_5.gap_description: WWW tries to be 'Hyper-Elevated' (Positioning). PDP brazenly displays '$9.97.' The marketplace is proving that the 'Masstige' proposition is the actual killer app.
truth_5.evidence: WWW: Visual focus on 'Luxury' vs. PDP: Visual focus on 'Value' ($9.97)
truth_5.why_matters: The website hides the price behind 'Clean Girl' aesthetics. Amazon puts the price front and center, and wins #1 Best Seller status. The website is ashamed of its greatest strength.
truth_5.the_hard_choice: Your website is pretending to be Sephora, but your bank account is fueled by Walmart. The Amazon success proves the price is the hook, not the shame. You must decide: either continue the 'Luxury' charade on the site to protect the brand aura (Option A), or pivot the site to aggressively own the 'Under $10' value prop and dominate the volume game globally (Option B). There is no shame in being the best affordable thing on earth.

marker_1.so_what: Minor drift in goal: WWW focuses on maintaining healthy skin, while PDP promises to fix dry skin. Negligible impact.

marker_2.so_what: Perfect alignment. The brand consistently signals that it is for everyone, everywhere.

marker_3.so_what: Both channels prioritize safety and gentle ingredients over aggressive performance claims.

marker_4.so_what: The 'Masstige' positioning is locked in. High-end look, mid-range reality.

marker_5.so_what: Consistent warmth and peer-to-peer dynamic across both touchpoints.

marker_6.so_what: Primary archetype matches perfectly. Secondary shifts from 'Jester' (Fun) on WWW to 'Innocent' (Safe) on PDP.

marker_7.so_what: WWW uses more Slang (Cool). PDP uses more Enthusiasm (Loud). Subtle but distinct energy shift.

marker_8.so_what: Visuals are perfectly synchronized. Soft pastels and playful chaos everywhere.

marker_9.so_what: Both channels sell the ingredient through the lens of romance and sensation.

marker_10.so_what: Consistent story: We are a big company (Nobel) sourcing from nature (Harvest).

marker_11.so_what: Validation gap. WWW leans on Awards. PDP leans on Review Count.

marker_12.so_what: Total ownership of 'Shea' as the hero ingredient across both channels.

marker_13.so_what: Content strategy is identical: Beautiful images used to pitch benefits.

marker_14.so_what: Product promise is consistent: Daily maintenance that feels good.

marker_15.so_what: WWW implies a deeper, more private retreat (Sanctuary) than PDP (Comfort).

marker_16.so_what: Both channels bet heavily on the 'Viral/Trending' status.

marker_17.so_what: Consistent social signaling: 'Everyone buys this, so you should too.'
